Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws c. 186, § 14, which provides tenants a statutory cause of action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: The Chelsea District Court has jurisdiction over landlord-tenant disputes and claims arising under G.L. c. 186 pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: The Chelsea District Court has jurisdiction over landlord-tenant disputes and claims arising under G.L. c. 186 pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 185C, § 3.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, meaning that the tenant shall not be disturbed in her possession by the landlord or by conditions caused or permitted by the landlord.

Alglow Realty Corp. v. Cent. Appraisal C.raw_text: Alglow Realty Corp. v. Cent. Appraisal Co., 379 Mass. 495 (1980)
Alglow Realty Corp. v. Cent. Appraisal C.proposition: Such failure constitutes a willful or negligent act or omission by the landlord that interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Alglow Realty Corp. v. Cent. Appraisal C.support_reasoning: The case is a contempt proceeding about failure to comply with a grand jury subpoena duces tecum. It does not involve a landlord‑tenant relationship, quiet enjoyment, or any discussion of willful or negligent acts by a landlord interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Citing this decision for the stated landlord‑tenant proposition would therefore be inaccurate and out of context.
Alglow Realty Corp. v. Cent. Appraisal C.relevant_excerpt: "We cannot uphold an adjudication of contempt in the total absence of evidence upon which such a finding could be based. It is well-settled that a person cannot be compelled to produce, under a subpoena, a document which is neither in his possession nor under his control; the burden falls on the government to establish such fact."

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Such failure constitutes a willful or negligent act or omission by the landlord that interferes with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that the landlord’s failure to provide heat—regardless of intent or financial inability—constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and mandates liability. It emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling and that liability arises whenever the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s action is interruption of the tenant’s rights. This directly supports the proposition that such a failure is a willful or negligent act or omission interfering with quiet enjoyment.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season… seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.raw_text: Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003)
Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.proposition: Defendant’s conduct is analogous to that found to violate quiet enjoyment in Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003) (landlord’s failure to remedy conditions interfering with access), Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (psychological distress actionable under covenant of quiet enjoyment), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord responsible for conditions substantially interfering with tenants’ use and enjoyment).
Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.case_name: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.
Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns solely whether a commercial tenant may bring a counterclaim in a commercial summary process action. It does not address the covenant of quiet enjoyment, access to premises, landlord liability for interference with use and enjoyment, or psychological distress. The case is therefore not analogous authority for a quiet enjoyment violation and does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.relevant_excerpt: “We transferred this case here on our own motion to decide whether a counterclaim may be filed in a commercial summary process action, particularly given the adoption of the rule of mutually dependant covenants in commercial leases…. Because we agree with the trial judge’s determination that a counterclaim is not a proper procedural device in a commercial summary process action, we affirm the judgment entered in the Superior Court.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant’s conduct is analogous to that found to violate quiet enjoyment in Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003) (landlord’s failure to remedy conditions interfering with access), Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (psychological distress actionable under covenant of quiet enjoyment), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord responsible for conditions substantially interfering with tenants’ use and enjoyment).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that emotional and psychological harm resulting from the landlord’s failure to maintain habitable, sanitary premises is compensable in connection with interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court explains that “actual and consequential damages” under § 14 encompass personal injuries, including emotional distress, where such harm is a foreseeable consequence of the landlord’s failure to maintain conditions, and it treats that emotional harm as part of the quiet enjoyment remedial scheme. Thus, Simon is properly cited for the proposition that psychological distress is actionable under the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises. … The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages, therefore, suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery. In the present case, not only were Solomon’s injuries foreseeable, but the jury found specifically that Gem knew or should have known that if it permitted floods to occur, Solomon would suffer emotional harm. Therefore, Solomon’s claim for emotional distress was within the scope of § 14 … .”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant’s conduct is analogous to that found to violate quiet enjoyment in Faford v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512 (2003) (landlord’s failure to remedy conditions interfering with access), Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (psychological distress actionable under covenant of quiet enjoyment), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977) (landlord responsible for conditions substantially interfering with tenants’ use and enjoyment).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord can be liable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where conditions originating from premises leased to another (here, a lounge) substantially interfere with the tenants’ use and enjoyment, and where the landlord has the ability to control or remedy those conditions. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct and control, not subjective intent, are determinative and that tenants need not be limited to claims against the third-party operator. This directly supports citing Blackett for the principle that a landlord is responsible for conditions substantially interfering with tenants’ use and enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain secure common areas and repair the entrance lock constitutes a defect in common areas under G.L. c. 186, § 15, which must be kept in a reasonably safe condition.

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain secure common areas and repair the entrance lock constitutes a defect in common areas under G.L. c. 186, § 15, which must be kept in a reasonably safe condition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 15 or analyze what constitutes a defect in common areas or an entrance lock. The only mention of locks is in a footnote listing ‘inadequate door locks’ among various State Sanitary Code violations in the tenant’s apartment; there is no treatment of common-area duties or a holding that failure to maintain secure common areas or repair the entrance lock is a statutory defect. Thus the case cannot be cited as authority for the stated proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: "The violations include the existence of lead paint, cracked windows, missing window screens, stained ceiling, loose bathroom tiles, mice, ants, missing balustrades on the porches, inadequate trash receptables, and inadequate door locks."

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: The unauthorized intrusions and theft resulting from Defendant’s inaction directly interfered with Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The case finds liability for substantial interference with the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment caused by the landlord’s authorized construction activities (noise, dust, obstruction, service interruptions), not for “unauthorized intrusions and theft” resulting from inaction. The court discusses wrongful invasions, nuisance, and trespass by or authorized by the landlord, and treats them as interferences with quiet enjoyment, but there is no mention of intruders, theft, or a theory based on the landlord’s failure to act. Thus the proposition mischaracterizes the facts and holding.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises and such a result is the natural and probable consequence of the acts so authorized, the landlord is liable therefor. … It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises….”

Whinery v. Robbins, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 34.raw_text: Whinery v. Robbins, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 343 (1983)
Whinery v. Robbins, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 34.proposition: The unauthorized intrusions and theft resulting from Defendant’s inaction directly interfered with Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment.
Whinery v. Robbins, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 34.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about jury selection, use of photographic identifications, evidentiary rulings, and the consequences of a missing trial transcript. It does not concern landlord–tenant law, property rights, quiet enjoyment, or liability for third‑party intrusions or theft. Because the court never addresses interference with quiet enjoyment or a defendant’s inaction regarding intrusions or theft, it cannot be cited as authority for that proposition.
Whinery v. Robbins, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 34.relevant_excerpt: In Massachusetts, the governing case is Commonwealth v. Harris, 376 Mass. 74 (1978). There a transcript was missing because of the theft of the stenographer’s notes. The Supreme Judicial Court ruled (at 78) that “the fact that the transcript is unavailable through no fault of the parties does not warrant a new trial unless the trial proceedings cannot be reconstructed sufficiently to present the defendant’s claims.”

Rich v. Ellerman, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 1037.raw_text: Rich v. Ellerman, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 1037 (1980)
Rich v. Ellerman, 10 Mass. App. Ct. 1037.proposition: The unauthorized intrusions and theft resulting from Defendant’s inaction directly interfered with Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a7 2.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated his duty under G.L. c. 93A, § 2 and 940 C.M.R. § 3.17(6) to maintain the premises in compliance with applicable landlord-tenant obligations, further evidencing negligent disregard for tenant safety (though Plaintiff asserts no separate statutory count herein).

940 C.M.R. \u00a7 3.17(6).proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violated his duty under G.L. c. 93A, § 2 and 940 C.M.R. § 3.17(6) to maintain the premises in compliance with applicable landlord-tenant obligations, further evidencing negligent disregard for tenant safety (though Plaintiff asserts no separate statutory count herein).

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Enter judgment for Plaintiff on the claim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14;
